title: Faulkner Fan Fic: Practicing Character Development and Scene Building in Faulkner’s Universe
description: This is a creative writing exercise which gives voice to minor characters in William Faulkner’s  universe. Students will use Digital Yoknapatawpha to flesh out minor characters and rewrite scenes in Faulkner’s fiction.
pilot_classroom: This project was piloted in a synchronous online creative writing class for college freshmen and sophomores at St. Louis Community College.
learning_goals: To identify major and minor characters, point of view, setting, scene building, and plot.
To research social/historical context in imaginative writing through the use of digital resources.
To practice stepping outside of self to write/invent characters and scenes from different perspectives in different time periods.
notes: Each activity can be used as scaffolded for the final product or can be used separately depending on the instructor’s desired outcomes.
You will need to allot some time to in-class instruction on Digital Yoknapatawpha.  The DY tools and pages for this assignment are fairly simple to use.

Community college students come in a wide range of ages and backgrounds. This class had high school dual-enrolled students as well as older adults who already had college degrees and were taking the course for enrichment. The project was successful considering the wide range of maturity and knowledge about Faulkner. Some students were aware of Faulkner’s work, some students had read Faulkner novels, and some students were introduced to Faulkner with this project.

title: As I Lay Dying Digital Escape Room
description: Students will use various DY tools to complete an escape room and acquire information regarding historical, geographical, and cultural context of the novel.
learning_goals: Students will use Digital Yoknapatawpha to deepen their understanding of how an author’s structural choices contribute to a text’s overall meaning and its aesthetic impact.
notes: As the instructor, you will likely want to change the “intro” information in the Google Form to suit your students and your classroom
Changing the passwords or passcodes affects the process of how the students move from one “room” to the next
Changing passwords or passcodes is only recommended for experienced users
Since you now have ownership of the form, you will also be provided with the answer key to each “room.”

title: Faulkner, Narration, and the New South Digital Yoknapatawpha "A Rose for Emily"
description: This lesson leads students to new discoveries of textual meaning and introduces them to twenty-first century job market skills.

title: "Barn Burning" and "The Man Who Was Almost a Man": Sharecropping and Coming of Age in Mississippi
description: Students will use DY maps and photos to study how Faulkner and Wright use the coming of age theme to examine sharecropping in the Jim Crow era.

paired_author.title: The Man Who Was Almost a Man

title: Bodily Autonomy in As I Lay Dying and "Bloodchild" by Octavia Butler
description: This module pairs As I Lay Dying with "Bloodchild" by Octavia Butler, and investigates how their protagonists struggle for bodily autonomy
pilot_classroom: This module was first taught in an online asynchronous course.

title: Bodily Autonomy in As I Lay Dying and "Woman Hollering Creek" by Sandra Cisneros
description: This module pairs As I Lay Dying with "Woman Hollering Creek" by Sandra Cisneros, and investigates how their female protagonists struggle for bodily autonomy.
pilot_classroom: This module was first taught in an online asynchronous course.

title: Bodily Autonomy in As I Lay Dying and "The Yellow Wallpaper" by Charlotte Perkins Gilman
description: This module pairs As I Lay Dying with "The Yellow Wallpaper" by Charlotte Perkins Gilman, and investigates how their female protagonists struggle for bodily autonomy
pilot_classroom: This module was first taught in an online asynchronous course.

title: Bodily Autonomy in As I Lay Dying and "Hills Like White Elephants" by Ernest Hemingway
description: This module pairs As I Lay Dying with "Hills Like White Elephants" by Ernest Hemingway, and investigates how their female protagonists struggle for bodily autonomy
pilot_classroom: This module was first taught in an online asynchronous course.

title: Bodily Autonomy in As I Lay Dying and A Streetcar Named Desire by Tennessee Williams
description: This module pairs As I Lay Dying with in Tennessee Williams’s play A Streetcar Named Desire, and investigates how their female protagonists struggle for bodily autonomy.
pilot_classroom: This module was first taught in an online asynchronous course.

title: Multimodal Composition and "A Rose for Emily"
description: Students will complete DY activities to respond critically to "A Rose for Emily", incorporating results as part of a multimodal essay assignment.

student_samples.title: "Let's Do the Time Warp Again":"A Rose for Emily" Analysis

title: Interpretive Mapping of Faulkner and Beyond
description: Students will interpret the fictions of Faulkner and other authors by mapping their texts.
pilot_classroom: Advanced Studies in Literature:  William Faulkner and James Fenimore Cooper
learning_goals: Understand how language shapes and influences understandings of place and space and, more specifically, how authors have created literary spaces that represent and respond to physical, cultural, historical and social contexts of Mississippi and New York
Develop the skills to shape complex questions and evaluate competing points of view about a text and explore understandings orally, visually, digitally, and in writing
Synthesize close readings and create multimodal texts that demonstrate understandings of audience, purpose, and context
Apply digital humanities research and conceptual skills for problem solving
notes: In an era of discussions of artificial intelligence complicating the literature classroom, these series of assignments helped students develop critical thinking and interpretive skills without writing a traditional literary essay. The maps students created of Cooper’s Templeton were thoughtful and creative and very, very different.   Some were craftier, one challenged my understanding of a map, and all demonstrated high level critical thinking skills, problem solving skills, and deep understandings of the text.  While this series of lessons was used in an advanced literature course, I also use many of these activities in introductory literature courses as well. These activities require students to do very close readings of a text and offer them opportunities to find location-specific contextual clues within particular passages.

title: Exploring the Worlds of Faulkner's Female Characters
description: Students will use multiple features of DY to consider how Faulkner writes his female characters. This lesson is focused on The Sound and the Fury but can be adapted for other Faulkner stories featuring central female characters.
pilot_classroom: This lesson was designed for a high school junior/senior advanced English elective at an all boys independent school in Washington, DC
notes: One of the most remarkable aspects of using DY to delve further into Caddy was the effect that it had on the teenage boys in my class. The act of visualizing Caddy's movements through DY and thus thinking about her beyond what we had heard about her from her brothers made them consider and ask important questions not just about Caddy, but about women in the American south in Faulkner's time (and now). DY allowed them to 'see' what it was like to be Caddy, and our consequent discussions--about how male writers write female characters, about how brothers view sisters, about Caddy herself--were memorable.

title: Using Digital Yoknapatawpha to Analyze Faulkner’s Absalom, Absalom! as a Gothic Text
description: This video presentation shows how to use DY's maps, visualizations, and indexes to analyze the Gothic in Absalom, Absalom!

title: Seeing Memory: Using Digital Yoknapatawpha to Teach Cognitive Literary Studies
description: This essay outlines how the instructor used DY to visualize Faulkner characters' struggles with the past and its persistence, entering a philosophical and scientific discussion.

title: Collaborating on a Genealogy for  As I Lay Dying
description: This is a multi-media project that connects writing and visual art, and pairs at-home student work with in-class collaboration and presentation.
pilot_classroom: Entry-level English major seminar at a liberal arts university.
learning_goals: Analyze text that emphasizes the significance of perspective in narrative texts
Critique implicit assumptions and limitations of reference tools such as genealogical charts
Work collaboratively to foster comparative analysis
Create artifacts that foster analysis across visual and textual media
notes: The student-presentation component makes this assignment work best in a seminar-sized class, where all have time to present. But it could be made to work in larger classes with a few adjustments to the presentation mode.

title: Using Digital Yoknapatawpha to Compare Interpretive Lenses for As I Lay Dying
description: These videos compare the interpretive lenses that can be applied to As I Lay Dying using DY.

title: DY When You Only Know 1 Faulkner Story
description: This video demonstrates how to use DY's search and keyword functions to take students deeper into "Dry September".

title: Space and Time in The Sound and the Fury
description: These videos demonstrate some of the ways to use DY in your classroom or research as well as develop a reading of some of The Sound and the Fury's major themes.

title: Using Digital Yoknapatawpha to Analyze "A Rose for Emily" as a Gothic Literary Work
description: This video demonstration illustrates how to use DY to perform a Gothic reading of Faulkner's "A Rose for Emily".

title: Digital Yoknapatawpha and the Pedagogical Pitfalls of Faulkner's The Sound and the Fury
description: This lesson is about some issues you might run into while teaching The Sound and the Fury using DY.

title: Tracking Themes in As I Lay Dying
description: This assignment asks students to re-imagine the fictions of Faulkner and other authors by mapping their texts.
learning_goals: Students will use Digital Yoknapatawpha in conjunction with the text to analyze how authors use motifs to reinforce themes in a fictional text

title: Love and Family in As I Lay Dying and Getting Mother’s Body
description: Students will read both novels and consider how Parks’ work speaks both back to and alongside Faulkner, particularly in terms of questions regarding family, obligation, and the possibilities of love in the midst of material and social marginalization.
learning_goals: Compare two formally and thematically related novels
